newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Business News - May 8.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Business News - May 8.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

In a deal expected to raise at least A$2.3 billion, the United Kingdom parent of ICI Australia, ICI plc, announced yesterday it would be selling its 62.4 per cent controlling stake in the company after being offered the chance to buy the speciality chemicls business of Unilever for A$10.2 billion. Page 1.

Federal Finance Minister John Fahey announced yesterday Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth airports had fetched A$3.337 billion collectively, suggesting the Coalition's total privatisation plan for Australia's airport network will reap A$6 billion-plus for the Government. Page 5.

Following several months of research, Australian analysts at United States-based investment facility Bankers Trust have predicted the price of copper will soar by 32 per cent by the end of 1998 on the back of an expected surge of demand in China. Such an ncrease would add about A$250 million to Australian annual export receipts and would see North Broken Hill, BHP, CRA and MIM becoming the immediate beneficiaries. Page 21.

The Australian Stock Exchange has bowed to pressure from institutional investors, with the board deciding to alter its eligibility criteria for stocks in the All Ordinaries Index from July 1 next year so that illiquid stocks are downweighted or dropped. The rejig will mean stocks must have an annual turnover of more than half the market turnover to remain fully represented in the index. Page 21.

Julian Baring, the London-based director of Mercury Asset Management International, which holds about half its funds' 3.5 billion pounds in gold, told reporters in Sydney yesterday Australian gold miners were forestalling any improvement in the gold price by continuing to forward sell, a decision he said sends the wrong message to investors. Page 23.

Following an announcement yesterday by Philippines' Mines and Geoscience Bureau director Horacio Ramos that the Government was negotiating with a group of international mining companies to develop a standard finance and technical assistance agreement for all mining projects, WMC Ltd could emerge as one of the major beneficiaries for the Tampakan copper/gold project. Page 23.
THE AUSTRALIAN

In a deal which frees ICI Australia Ltd to expand its fast-growing explosives and consumer products businesses in Asia, the company's British parent of 69 years, Imperial Chemical Industries Plc, announced last night it would sell its 62.4 per cent stake n its Australian subsidiary in a selldown worth A$2.3 billion. Page 19.

Despite a Federal Government ban on wholesale ownership changes to the winning consortiums of the Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth airports, public investors will be able to gain backdoor exposure to Australia's privatised airports as two of the successful bdders plan a public listing and the third will offer investment through an existing listed associate. Page 19.

Although Pasminco Ltd will not formally acquire Century Zinc Ltd, the operator of Queensland's world-class Century zinc mine, until around August, chief executive David Stewart has announced the company will move to cut capital costs below A$1 billion at he project following yesterday's historic native title agreement between project owner RTZ-CRA, the Queensland Government, and Gulf Aborigines. Page 19.

In a decision which indicates initial inquiries by the Australian Stock Exchange uncovered sufficient reason to conduct a wider investigation, the Australian Securities Commission announced yesterday it would be conducting a formal investigation into pre-takeover share trading in Westpac Banking Corp's controversial A$1.4 billion bid for the Bank of Melbourne. Page 19.

Clifford Einstein QC, who is appearing against Telstra Corp for service provider QAI Australia, told the Federal Court yesterday the ongoing dispute between the national carrier and service providers over alleged problems with the Telstra billing system hd left Telstra with about A$500 million in outstanding debt. Page 21.

In the second discovery in South Australia's gas-rich Copper-Eromanga Basin this year, oil and gas producer Santos yesterday announced its fourth successful gas exploration well in 1997. Initial drills at the Goyder 2 site, 39 kilometres south-east of Moomba, show gas flows from two separate formations of more than 154,000 cubic metres a day. Page 21.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

In a decision that caught the sharemarket by surprise, the United Kingdom-based Imperial Chemicals Industries announced yesterday it will quit Australia after 70 years by selling its A$2.3 billion shareholding in ICI Australia to institutional investors bfore the end of 1997, providing market conditions are suitable. Page 27.

Federal Finance Minister John Fahey and Transport Minister John Sharp yesterday revealed the winning bidders for the 50-year leases over three of Australia's airports - Melbourne, Perth and Brisbane - and announced the Federal Government will pocket A$3.3billion from the sales, more than twice the sum originally expected. Page 27.

Colonial Ltd chief executive Peter Smedley revealed yesterday the bank and insurance group's share offer to retail investors, which closed on Tuesday, has been oversubscribed almost 10 times, suggesting next week's institutional share offer will produce a final price well above the A$2.60-a-share base. Page 27.

The Australian Securities Commission revealed yesterday it is investigating trading in Bank of Melbourne shares in the lead-up to Westpac Banking Corporation's A$1.4 billion takeover bid for the regional after having the case referred to it by the Australan Stock Exchange about two weeks ago. Page 27. --

Following talks with the Reserve Bank earlier this week to discuss AMP's application for a banking licence, chief executive George Trumbull said current regulations permitted AMP to take only deposits by issuing a prospectus or by owning a banking licence and he predicted a key recommendation of the Wallis report to broaden the variety of deposit-taking institutions would be rejected. Page 29.

In a move which comes as the New South Wales Government prepares to appoint a float adviser and announce the new TAB board by the end of May, State Treasurer Michael Egan has sent a letter to the chief executives of New South Wales' registered clubs in an effort to dispel their concerns over the A$1.5 billion TAB float. Page 29.
THE AGE

Britain's giant ICI group is preparing to sell its 62 per cent, A$2.3 billion stake in ICI Australia, ending 120-years of association. Australian investors will be shocked by the move as they expected British ICI to consolidate its hold on the company bybuying out minority shareholders. Analysts expect ICI shares will drop below A$11 in today's trading. Page B1.

The Australian Securities Commission has begun investigations into suspect trading in Bank of Melbourne Ltd shares that occurred immediately prior to Westpac unveiling its takeover plans in April. In particular, the ASC is concerned about several transacions on April 2, the day before Westpac and the Bank of Melbourne announced their merger plans. Page B1.

New figures released yesterday by the car industry monitor VFacts reveal car sales in April increased 14 per cent from last year to 42,137. However, this boom did not help local manufacturers who hold just 47 per cent of the market, down from the 54 per ent enjoyed at the same time last year. Page B1.

The Federal Government has yielded to pressure to extend the five per cent bounty on ships built by June 30 1999 for another 18-months, partially reversing a 1996-97 budget decision to axe the subsidy. The Federal Government was lobbied to change its postion by the industry, State Governments, and Opposition parties. Page B3.

Colonial's share offer to retail investors has been oversubscribed by nearly 10 times, with the company expecting a final share price above the predicted A$2.60. Sources predict retail investors who took part in the public float will now get around 300 o the share and option packages, far below the minimum application of 1000 shares each. Page B3.

Vitamin and health supplements company Blackmores yesterday announced a 25 per cent rise in third-quarter profits to A$2.9 million, largely due to improved operating margins. Following the announcement, Blackmores said it will continue its buyback of 500,000 company shares. Page B3.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
